review_title: Impactful nonprofit with great culture and terrific people!
pros: I've worked at for-profit and non-profit organizations in the past and HSL stands out for having a strong culture, amazing and caring staff, and impactful work. A place where a number of employees have worked more than 50 years! A place with professional development opportunities. And lots going on to keep things interesting !
cons: No organization is perfect or can be great at everything. I can't think of any cons that are major or unusual for many organizations. E.g., I would like to see diversity of staff at senior levels increase. Some departments feel a bit under-resourced (including funds to invest for systems).

pros: Great mission, many wonderful colleagues.
cons: Low pay for market. At the time, the management in the development/business offices was horrible. Can't speak for present day.

pros: Good environment to work. Great!
cons: The pay could be better!

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Dedham, MA
pros:
The pay for new grad BSNs is higher than Boston-area hospitals, starting at $32.44.
You accrue and can utilize your vacation and sick time immediately.
Clean environment.
cons:
Very little, if any social justice, diversity/inclusion training.
Nursing retention issues & short-staffed.
Often forced to work overtime on short or no notice due to oncoming staff lateness.
1 N: 22 P ratio in LTC, not many of the patients are as stable as you think.
Not many skill-building opportunities for new grads, for example, RNs are not allowed to initiate IVs.
No more COVID sick time.

pros: PTO, great management, free parking, great benefits
cons: None, this is a great place to work

pros: The Dedham Campus was very nicely kept.
cons: The most toxic HR group I have ever worked in. Constant gossip starting at the Chief HR Officer level and throughout the rest of the HR team. Nothing was kept confidential, everyone gossiped about not only each other but the employees of the organization. The leader of the HR team is an absolute joke. Discrimination, bullying, favortism, etc. all within an HR team. I learned how NOT to be an HR Leader from her.

pros: Excellent coworker, clean, friendly housekeeping staff
cons: Lack of communication, Parking sucks,

pros: The only perks are the benefits and the on site parking
cons:
Rampant sexism from managers to upper management. They openly tell women to watch their tone in emails, while letting male coworkers get away with toxic language and behavior in person as well as in emails. Women are held to a markedly higher standard than men. Frequently heard managers use " the b word" to describe female employees. 
A female employee was given a work review in which she was told to "smile more" when coming within a certain distance of other employees.
They frequently force you to work well over 40 hours without overtime. 
People treat each other terribly, it's a very negative environment; I wouldn't go so far as to say toxic, but it's on its way to being toxic.

review_title: A good employer for those approaching retirement
pros: HSL's Marcus Institute had good work life balance and the junior staff where high quality.  Senior faculty and center directors were smart and ambitious, and and there were opportunities for conference presentations for motivated junior staff in many centers.
cons: HSL did not provide any bonuses or incentives for good performance, beyond an up to 4% yearly raise.  4% is a cost of living adjustment and inflation adjustment in the Boston area.  They also did not provide any maternity leave beyond the state-required short-term disability coverage.  403b contribution matching was below average.

pros: This is a mid-sized rehabilitation agency that also has a research department. If you want to learn more about patient care and research concerning older patients, this place is a great resource. Many of the staff I interacted with are very caring and supportive. Work-life balance is good.
cons: Human Resources team is notorious for losing documents and sending offer letters with incorrect or missing information. Management is very disorganized -- especially when it comes to having staff & management follow proposed rules consistently. Organization is not as transparent as they should be. Research funding is inadequate for many of the important studies. Pay scale is definitely on the lower end of the scale across the board.

pros: There is a lot of diversity amongst the employees, mutual respect, and teamwork. There is always the exceptional shift when people aren't perfect but overall it is a great environment. The facility is extremely clean, has a home rather than institutional feel to it. Rehab is a busy floor but lots to learn and lots of support from co-workers and manager and practitioners.
cons: Compensation isn't horrible but it definitely could be better in comparison to other places

review_title: Good place to work, just need to find your fit
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Roslindale, MA
pros: Overall a good company to work for, they have a great mission and everyone seems to follow it.
cons: No two departments or teams are alike. Sometimes you may not be a good fit in one department so you should always look into other opportunities within the company if you are unhappy. They like to keep talent in the company which is great.

review_title: Newer campus in Dedham. Nice people.
pros: Beautiful campus in dedham. it was only built a few years ago. Everyone I encountered there was pleasant and very friendly. There is a variety of residents there, so whether you want to work with higher functioning or lower functioning elders, there are opportunities.
cons: The hiring process takes a long time, but HR is very helpful. Parking can be tricky in certain areas of the campus.

pros: Great work environment breeding high employee morale. Employees are regularly recognized for their contributions and hard work. Many opportunities for staff and residents to interact. Food is top notch! Supervisors are generally supportive. There are also many opportunities to grow professionally and to get involved at Harvard Medical School.
cons: Pay could be more competitive for junior researchers! Plan for promotion may not always be clear.

pros: Worked in smaller group off the main corporate campus.  Co-workers were amazing with a true Team mentality and fun atmosphere.  Challenging work but very rewarding.
cons: New management made life very difficult, The non-profit became very corporate and concentrated on the bottom line and not the mission.

review_title: Great company to start my career in Senior Recreation with.

pros: Benefits are good, upper management seeks input of employees, excellent senior care, high value placed on quality of life for residents
cons: Lots of management turnover, little room for growth, inconsistent expectations, high turnover in HR and lack of general HR presence, very disappointing tuition reimbursement rate ($1000/year)

review_title: They walk the talk when it comes to people!
pros: This organization truly cares about its culture and people.  It also works hard to "ask what matters" to its employees and its patients/residents.
cons: Like any mission based organization, they have to be careful of spending so salaries may slightly lag behind the market.

pros: I enjoyed working here due to the environment and people!  It was great learning about the residents' stories,  and you make great friends with coworkers,  working so closely with one another.
cons: The raises as a server can be minimal - 20¢ or so every year.
